programme.title: Eli Roth's History of Horror
programme.desc: The history of monster movies is also the history of the evolution of special effects technology; whatever their size or shape and whatever they represent, for many horror fans monsters are the best part of the genre.

programme.title: Eli Roth's History of Horror
programme.desc: Sometimes disgusting, body horror films make audience members question their prejudices against physical difference, their attitudes about sex and gender, their fear of disease and contamination, and how much appearance determines destiny.

programme.title: Eli Roth's History of Horror
programme.desc: The witch is a towering figure in the history of horror; the archetypical evil witch is everything mainstream religion tells believers a woman should not be -- and that unapologetic, very female power frightens men and fascinates women.

programme.title: Eli Roth's History of Horror
programme.desc: Parents are supposed to love their children, no matter how awful their kids may be; the films highlighted in this episode may not solve the mystery of where evil comes from, but they have a terrifically terrifying time raising the question.

programme.title: Eli Roth's History of Horror
programme.desc: A deep dive into nine films that defy categorization and push the boundaries of horror; great films that entertain and provoke audiences; films that put society under a microscope, making people question not just what they fear, but why they fear it.

programme.title: Eli Roth's History of Horror
programme.desc: Home is where the heart is, unless one lives in a house of hell; whether they're filled with specters or psychos, every house of hell pokes at illusions of comfort and safety.
